arm_group.description: Using the blended technique device operators will establish proximal humerus intraosseous vascular access.

brief_summary.textblock:
A Follow-up Study Validating a Blended Technique for Identifying the Proximal Humerus
      Intraosseous Vascular Access Insertion Site

clinical_study.brief_title: Follow-Up Study Validating a Blended Technique

detailed_description.textblock:
In 2012, the investigators from Vidacare evaluated 4 techniques commonly used to identify
      the proximal humerus IO insertion site to determine if one technique resulted in more
      consistent successful placement of the IO needle set with a higher level of confidence among
      device operators performing the techniques. Results suggest that a combination of the best
      features of the 4 techniques may lead to optimal IO needle set placement more consistently.
      This study is needed to validate the "Blended" proximal humerus IO insertion technique to
      confirm that use of the technique results in proper site identification among device
      operators and results in increased confidence.To most closely evaluate the Blended proximal
      humerus insertion technique and how it is received by clinicians who perform these
      procedures in actual patients, device operators will include licensed/certified clinicians
      including, emergency medicine technicians/paramedics and nurses.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Currently licensed/certified Emergency Medicine Technicians, paramedic, or nurse Have
             had no formal training on use of the proximal humerus IO insertion site Demonstrate
             proper use of the device and technique during training portion and obtain approval
             from the device trainer to participate

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Previous training on establishing proximal humerus intraosseous vascular access

intervention.description: Using the blended technique, device operators will establish proximal humerus intraosseous vascular access by inserting an IO needle.

clinical_study.official_title: A Follow-up Study Validating a Blended Technique for Identifying the Proximal Humerus Intraosseous Vascular Access Insertion Site

primary_outcome.description: Successful IO needle insertion determined by x-ray images
primary_outcome.time_frame: Day 1 after establishing proximal humerus IO vascular access

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Intraosseous infusion flow rates attained using 4 different infusion pressures Gravity; 100 mmHg, 200 mmHg and 300 mmHg.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Day 1 after establishing IO vascular access

secondary_outcome.measure: Time in seconds for fluid delivery from the proximal humerus to the heart, using visualization of contrast injection under fluoroscopy.

secondary_outcome.description: IO blood and peripheral venous blood will be collected and analyzed for routine blood tests and the results will be compared to determine if there is a relationship.
secondary_outcome.measure: Relationship between IO and peripheral venous blood
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Day 1 after establishing IO vascular access and peripheral venous access

clinical_study.study_design: Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label
